Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing multi-scale drivers of pollinator assembly and plant-pollinator network architecture in the context of prairie restoration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pollinators are key to the maintenance of Earth's biodiversity because almost 90% of flowering plants rely on animal pollinators to reproduce. Pollinators are also a vital component of global agriculture, and pollination services by insects are worth hundreds of billions of dollars annually. Given their importance, it is critical that we develop an understanding of how insect pollinator communities interact with plants across complex landscapes that are often heavily modified by humans. Researchers have recently begun using "network" approaches to study plant-pollinator interactions across entire ecological communities. A plant-pollinator network can be visualized as a "web" of all interactions between pollinators and plants at a given place. By building and evaluating plant-pollinator networks, researchers can, for example, assess whether pollination at a given site will remain stable in the face of disturbance or loss of species. This is especially relevant, considering that human-induced stressors, such as habitat loss and pesticide use, are causing pollinator declines worldwide. This research will use a new genetic approach to determine which plant species are pollinated by which bee species in ten Kansas prairies. Data will be used to construct plant-pollinator networks to assess the potential effect of disturbance and loss of pollinator species on pollination services across human-modified landscapes. As part of this project, the research team will conduct pollinator ecology workshops for middle- and high school students aspiring to be first-generation college graduates.

Plant-pollinator networks are typically constructed from observations of insects landing on flowers (i.e., "visitation networks"). Few researchers have evaluated these insects for the presence and species identities of pollen carried between flowers; doing so based on pollen morphology is especially time-consuming. In this project, investigators will use metabarcoding to identify pollen carried by native bees collected across ten study sites. Several structural properties of the resulting pollen transport networks will be compared to the properties of networks based on visitation data alone. Investigators predict that: A) pollen transport networks will exhibit greater network-level specialization than visitation networks, and B) pollen transport networks will be less nested than visitation networks, indicating that plant-pollinator interactions could be more susceptible to species loss than the visitation data, alone, would suggest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction and Project Goals:

Insect pollinators, and the pollination services they provide to both crop- and wild plants, are critical to maintaining plant biodiversity and global food security. The recent adoption of plant-pollinator networks (similar to food webs, but documenting the interactions between insects and flowers; Fig. 1) to study the community-wide interactions between flowering plants and their visitors has greatly enhanced our understanding of the ecological and evolutionary processes that underpin these complex, interacting communities. Plant-pollinator networks, and the detailed information they provide to ecologists and practitioners, can also be extremely useful for developing pollinator conservation and recovery plans across a wide array of ecosystems.

 

To date, the vast majority of plant-pollinator networks have been based solely on observations of insect visitation (?visitation networks?), and few studies have ?built? networks based on pollen recovered from the bodies of insect visitors (?pollen transport networks?), owing to the labor-intensive process of identifying pollen based on morphology. This is especially true in ecosystems with relatively high levels of floral, and thus, pollen, diversity. This is concerning, as insects come into contact with flowers for a variety of reasons that may not result in pollen transfer, which could lead researchers to draw erroneous conclusions about the true nature of plant-pollinator network structure, thus affecting our understanding of the ecology, evolution and conservation needs of these communities.

 

Our overarching goals for this project were to (1) determine whether a recently developed ITS2 metabarcoding approach to building pollen transport networks was feasible in an ecosystem with a relatively high level of both flowering-plant and bee diversity; and (2) compare the structural properties of traditional, visitation-based plant-bee networks with pollen transport networks utilizing the same bee specimens. This study was conducted across remnant and reconstructed tallgrass prairies in Kansas, USA, an ecosystem that has experienced extensive destruction and degradation due to agricultural conversion. Bees were the specific focus of this study, as they are considered the most efficient pollinating insect and are the dominant pollinators across a wide array of ecosystems.

 

Preliminary Results and Broader Impacts

 

We have successfully completed pollen DNA extraction and sequencing for bee specimens collected across 2 remnant (unplowed) prairies and 2 reconstructed (former row crop) prairies in northeast Kansas (Figure 2). We are using a QIIME2-based bioinformatics pipeline to identify pollen grains from the target bee samples. Samples analyzed thus far show 90% success at recovering plant communities from DNA of the preserved bee specimens. Sequencing information (e.g. depth) was approximately equal among bee specimens and not clearly related to bee taxonomy. From these data, plant taxa present as pollen included plant species upon which the bees were visually observed, other plants recorded in-flower at the study sites on the collection dates, and both angiosperm and non-angiosperm species that were not recorded in our field notes (likely blooming within 1 km of the study sites). Our ongoing work involves constructing a phylogenetic tree of potential plant species present as pollen, which is necessary to more accurately match pollen sequences to plant taxa. The high pollen diversity in this system has complicated this process, requiring the collection of more complete sequencing data and the creation of a robust plant phylogenetic tree to which we can compare the pollen data generated thus far. Once the bioinformatics stage of the project is completed (anticipated spring 2020), we will generate pollen transport networks and evaluate network nestedness (WNODF), modularity (Qnorm), specialization (H2?) and robustness to simulated species loss, comparing these networks? values to those generated from visitation networks.

 

The full visitation networks (which non-bee pollinators) are significantly non-nested, modular and specialized, indicating that interaction partitioning is a fundamental feature plant-pollinator networks in this system. In addition, shared forb and flower visitor taxa exhibited similar interaction specialization across both types of prairie. Furthermore, networks were highly robust to simulated species loss, suggesting current prairie reconstruction practices are successfully reinstating these critical interactions.

 

This project has led to numerous opportunities to educate the broader public about the importance of pollinating insects and involve citizen scientists in pollinator monitoring schemes. We have collaborated with groups across Kansas and Missouri, including the Missouri Department of Conservation, Johnson Co. (KS) Parks & Recreation, and Rockhurst University to develop and implement a pollinator monitoring protocol at several locations in the Kansas City area and surrounding communities. The most recent of these efforts is planned for Fall 2020, during which Gardner Edgerton (KS) high school students and representatives from the Miami Co. (KS) Conservation district will begin monitoring native bees on a 500 acre prairie reconstruction in northeast Kansas.
